title: Will Hurricane Dorian affect the Mid-Atlantic and Washington?
text:
Dorian became one of the most intense Atlantic hurricanes ever recorded Sunday as it plowed over the northern Bahamas. The storm is next predicted to threaten Florida’s east coast before barreling up the Southeast coast from Georgia to the Carolinas.

The North Carolina Outer Banks face a serious risk from Dorian later this week, and it’s possible that the storm will brush Virginia Beach and the Delmarva area, including the Maryland and Delaware beaches.

[Historic Hurricane Dorian unleashing ‘catastrophic’ blow in northern Bahamas, hurricane warnings posted for Florida’s east coast]

At this point, there is only a small possibility that the storm will skirt the immediate Washington area, but it’s something we’ll need to watch as this track forecast comes into better focus.

The zone of greatest concern by far is from near Wilmington, N.C., to the Outer Banks, where forecast models show Dorian’s center very close Thursday night into Friday. Conditions in this area could begin deteriorating as soon as early Thursday. If the storm makes a close pass, either making landfall in this zone or not far from it, dangerous hurricane conditions would be possible Thursday night and Friday.

In coastal North Carolina, major flooding could result from the storm surge, the storm-driven rise in ocean water above normally dry land. Five to 10 inches of rain could also fall, with winds exceeding hurricane force. The storm is projected to decrease in strength by the time it reaches the Mid-Atlantic — probably closer to Category 2 than 5.

Some of these storm hazards could bleed into Virginia Beach and Delmarva, but it’s unlikely that the center of the storm would come particularly close. Tropical-storm rather than hurricane conditions are possible, mainly on Friday.

The storm will be moving fairly quickly by the time it affects the Mid-Atlantic, so excessive rainfall and inland flooding probably will be limited compared with past storms such as Florence and Floyd.

Of course, forecast specifics are highly dependent on the storm’s course, and track forecasts have large errors this many days in advance. If Dorian tracks more to the east, even the North Carolina coast may be skirted while areas farther north receive little wind and rain. If it tracks more to the west, areas farther inland into the piedmont areas of North Carolina and Virginia, and the interior Delmarva, may briefly deal with tropical storm conditions.

For the immediate Washington area, the odds of much more than some gusty showers are small in almost any scenario, but if the storm tracks west, eastern areas near the Chesapeake Bay could see a short period of stormy weather.

Irrespective of the exact track, beach erosion, rough surf, rip currents and at least minor coastal flooding will become a concern by the middle of the week at beaches.

Stay tuned for additional updates as the forecast becomes clearer.
